Introduction

Welcome to the Python track. This course is built for biologists who want to move from manual work to reliable, repeatable analysis. We start small and practical: reading sequences, cleaning data, and getting comfortable with the ideas behind variables and functions.

You will learn by doing. Each section has a short explanation, a real example, and a place to try the code. Think of it as a lab notebook for programming: you test, observe the output, and adjust your approach.

By the end, you will be able to handle files, analyze biological data, and build small tools that save time in real projects. Use the Next button to move step by step, and the sidebar to jump to any topic.

Python is a programming language, which means it is a way to write instructions that the computer can understand and follow step by step.

Python works as an interpreter, which means it runs your code line by line and shows the result immediately, so you can test and fix things easily.

Python is popular in biology because it can work with sequences, files, tables, and large datasets using simple and readable code.

Example

Note:print() is used to show something on the screen.


Biology Examples

Example

Note:len()gives the length of a sequence or text.

How to Download and Install Python (Windows / Mac / Linux)

Before writing any Python code, you need to install Python on your computer. Don?t worry, this is a one-time setup and after this you won?t need to touch it again.

First, check if Python is already installed

Open Command Prompt / Terminal and type: 

    python --version
    or
    python3 --version

If you see a version number, Python is already there. If not, follow the steps below.

Installing on Windows

Go to python.org and click the big Download button for Windows.

Open the downloaded file.

Before clicking install, make sure you tick:
? Add Python to PATH

Then click Install Now and wait.

After installation, open Command Prompt and type: 

    python --version

If it shows a version, Python is ready.

Installing on macOS

Go to python.org and download the macOS installer.

Open the file and just click Continue until it finishes.

After that, open Terminal and type: 

        python3 --version

If you see a version, Python is working.

Installing on Linux (Ubuntu/Debian)

Open Terminal and type: 

    sudo apt install python3

After it finishes, check: 

    python3 --version

Small test to be sure everything works

Create a file named test.py and write:

Example

Run it: 

    python test.py
    or
    python3 test.py

If it prints the message, everything is correct. 

    Python is ready

Installing Visual Studio Code, Jupyter Notebook, and PyCharm

Python code needs a place to be written and run. Some people like a simple editor, some like a notebook style, and some like a full software for big projects.

Here we will set up three popular tools. You don?t have to use all three forever, but it?s good to try them once and see what you like.

1) Visual Studio Code (VS Code)

VS Code is like a smart notebook for writing code.

Go to: code.visualstudio.com

Download and install it like normal software.

After opening VS Code:
Click the Extensions icon on the left
Search for: Python
Install the one by Microsoft

Now create a file named test.py and write:

Example

Run it and check the output.

2) Jupyter Notebook

Jupyter Notebook is used when you want to run code step by step and see output immediately, like a lab notebook.

Open Command Prompt / Terminal and type: 

            pip install notebook

Then start it: 

            jupyter notebook

Your browser will open. Click New ? Python 3 and write:

Example

Run the cell and see the output.

3) PyCharm

PyCharm is a full software made specially for Python. It is good for bigger projects.

Go to: jetbrains.com/pycharm

Download the Community Edition and install it.

Open PyCharm ? Create a new project ? Create a Python file ? Write:

Example

Run the file and check the output.

Important:
? If you are a beginner: Start with VS Code or Jupyter
? If you later work on big projects: Try PyCharm

Note: These tools are not Python. They are just places where you write and run Python code.

Sometimes you want to write notes inside your code so that you (or someone else) can understand it later. Python ignores these notes when the program runs. These notes are called comments.

Single-line comments

Variables

When you write programs, you often need to store values and use them again and again. Variables are the way Python does this.

In this topic, you will learn how to store data, change it, reuse it, and manage it properly inside your programs.

Here you will learn:

  • How values are kept in memory using names
  • How to change and reuse stored values
  • How to assign multiple values
  • How variables behave inside and outside parts of a program

By the end of this topic, you will be comfortable using variables in every Python program you write

What are Variables

When a program runs, it needs a way to remember values and use them again later.
In Python, a variable is just a name given to a value so you can use that value again and again.
You can think of a variable as a label that points to some data.

Variables illustration

Simple examples

Here, a value is given a name and used later.

Once a value is stored, you can use it anywhere.

Used in: Storing sequences, keeping counts, saving results, and passing values between different parts of a script.

Naming Rules and Best Practices

Variable names are used to identify your data, so they should be written in a way that is easy to read and understand. Python has a few simple rules for naming variables, and following them avoids many mistakes.

Valid variable names

A variable name can contain letters, numbers, and _, but it cannot start with a number. 

age = 21
user_name = "Amar"
score1 = 95
_value = 10
total_sum = 100

Invalid variable names

These names will cause errors. 

# 1age = 20
# user-name = "A"
# total sum = 50

Note: Names with spaces or - are not allowed, and names cannot start with a number.

Good naming practice

Clear names make code easier to read later.

Example

Biology example

Example

Quick summary ? Naming rules

  • A variable name must start with a letter or _(Underscore)
  • It can contain letters, numbers, and _(Underscore)
  • It cannot start with a number
  • It cannot contain spaces
  • It should not use -(hyphen)
  • Use meaningful names instead of single letters when possible

Used in: Writing readable scripts, managing many values, and avoiding confusion in long biology programs.

Global and Local Variables

Variables can live in different parts of a program. Some are created at the top and can be used everywhere, and some are created inside a block and are meant to be used only there.
For now, we will understand this using simple code blocks. We will see the full picture again when we learn functions.

Global variable (created at top level)

A variable created outside any block is available everywhere in the program.

Example

These are global because they are written at the top and not inside any block.

Local variable (created inside a block)

A variable created inside a block is meant to be used only inside that block.

Data Types

When you store values in variables, not all values are the same. Some are numbers, some are text, some are true/false, and some represent “nothing”.

Python uses data types to understand what kind of data it is working with and what can be done with that data.

In this topic, you will learn:

  • What data types are and why they matter
  • How to work with numbers, text, and true/false values
  • How to convert one type to another
  • How Python represents empty or missing values
  • How to do basic math operations safely

By the end of this topic, you will be comfortable choosing and using the right type of data in your programs.

What are Data Types

When you store something in a variable, Python does not only store the value, it also remembers what kind of value it is. This “kind of value” is called a data type.

Data types are important because Python uses them to decide what you can do with the value, how operations behave, and how the value is stored and handled.

For example, numbers are used for calculations, text is used for names and sequences, and true/false values are used for decisions.

Main categories of data in Python

  • Numbers → for counts, lengths, scores, positions
  • Strings → for text, names, DNA/RNA/protein sequences
  • Boolean → for True/False checks
  • None → for “no value” or “empty result”
  • Collections → for storing many values together

You will learn all of these step by step in this topic and the next topics.

Built-in data types in Python (important to know)

Category Type name Used for Example
Number int Whole numbers 10, 250, -3
Number float Decimal numbers 3.14, 45.6
Text str Text and sequences "Hello", "ATGC"
Logic bool True / False values True, False
Empty NoneType No value None
Collection list List of values (changeable) [1, 2, 3]
Collection tuple List of values (fixed) (1, 2, 3)
Collection set Unique values {1, 2, 3}
Collection dict Key–value pairs {"a": 1, "b": 2}

You don’t need to remember all of them now — you will use them naturally as we go forward.

Seeing different data types

Example

Example

Note: type() tells you what kind of data a value is.

Example

Some operations only make sense for certain types. Numbers can be added, but a number and text cannot be added directly.

Used in: Choosing the right kind of data, avoiding type mistakes, handling sequences as text and results as numbers, and writing reliable analysis scripts.

This is very common when working with user input, file data, or mixed values.

Python string

In biology and in general programming, text data is everywhere — names, IDs, sequences, file paths, messages, and reports. In Python, all such text is handled using strings.

A string is simply a sequence of characters stored inside quotes.

In this topic, you will learn:

  • What strings are and how to create them
  • How to access parts of a string
  • How to cut (slice), join, and modify strings
  • How to format text with values
  • How to use useful string methods for searching and changing text

By the end of this topic, you will be comfortable working with DNA/RNA/protein sequences, names, and any text data using Python strings

What is String

A string is used to store text data in Python. Text can be anything: names, messages, file paths, or even DNA/RNA/protein sequences.

In Python, a string is written inside quotes — either single quotes ' ' or double quotes " ".

Creating strings

You can create a string by writing text inside quotes.

Indexing

A string is a sequence of characters, and each character has a position number. Using these position numbers, you can access a single character from the string. This is called indexing.

In Python, indexing starts from 0, not 1.

Basic indexing

You can get a character by using square brackets [] with the index number.

Slicing

Slicing is used when you want to take a part of a string instead of just one character. Using slicing, you can extract a range of characters from a string.

Slicing does not change the original string — it creates a new string.

Basic slicing

The general form is: 

                text[start : end]

This means: take characters from position start up to but not including position end.

Python Operators

Operators are symbols that tell Python to perform an action on values, like adding numbers, comparing values, or combining conditions.

You already use operators without noticing, like + in addition or > in comparisons.

In this topic, you will learn:

  • How Python does calculations using operators
  • How to update values using shortcut operators
  • How to compare values and make decisions
  • How to combine multiple conditions
  • How Python checks identity and membership
  • How operator precedence affects results

By the end of this topic, you will be comfortable using operators in calculations, filtering data, and writing decision logic in biology scripts.

What is Operators

In Python, operators are special symbols that are used to perform actions on values or variables. They tell Python what to do with the data, like add two numbers, compare two values, or check a condition.

You have already seen operators in simple programs, even without calling them “operators”. For example, + is used to add, = is used to store a value, and > is used to compare values.

Think of it like this:

  • values are the data.
  • operators are the actions performed on that data.

Bitwise Operators

Bitwise operators work on numbers at the binary (bit) level. Instead of working with whole numbers, they work with the individual 0s and 1s inside the number.

These operators are mostly used in low-level programming, optimization, flags, and special calculations. You will not use them very often in basic biology scripts, but it is good to know what they are.

Python has the following bitwise operators:

  • & (AND)
  • | (OR)
  • ^ (XOR)
  • ~ (NOT)
  • << (Left shift)
  • >> (Right shift)

Bitwise AND (&)

The AND operator compares each bit and returns 1 only if both bits are 1.

Example

Bitwise OR (|)

The OR operator compares each bit and returns 1 if at least one bit is 1.

Example

Bitwise XOR (^)

The XOR operator returns 1 if the bits are different.

Example

Bitwise NOT (~)

The NOT operator inverts all bits.

Example

Note: The result looks strange because Python uses signed numbers internally.

Left shift (<<)

Left shift moves bits to the left and adds zeros on the right. This is like multiplying by powers of 2.

Example

Right shift (>>)

Right shift moves bits to the right. This is like dividing by powers of 2.

Example

Simple practical idea

Bitwise operators are often used to store and check flags using numbers.

Example

Biology note

In most biology scripts, you will rarely need bitwise operators. They are mainly useful in special tools, performance optimization, or compact data storage.

Used in: Low-level operations, flags, performance optimization, compact data storage, and special algorithm implementations.

Operator Precedence

When you write an expression that contains more than one operator, Python must decide which operation to do first. This rule system is called operator precedence.

Operator precedence is similar to the rules you learned in mathematics, where multiplication is done before addition.

For example:

Example

Here, Python first does 5 * 2 and then adds 10, so the result is:

Example

If Python did addition first, the result would be different, but it does not.

Another example

Example

Here, division happens first, then subtraction.

Using parentheses to control order

You can use parentheses ( ) to force Python to do some operations first.

Example

Example

General precedence idea (simplified)

  • Parentheses ( ) are done first
  • Then power **
  • Then multiplication, division, floor division, modulo * / // %
  • Then addition and subtraction + -
  • Then comparisons, logical operators, etc.

You do not need to memorize the full table. If something looks confusing, just use parentheses.

Example

Here, comparison operators run before logical operators.

Why precedence matters

These two results are different because the order of operations is different.

Important rule

If you are ever unsure about the order of operations, use parentheses to make it clear.

Used in: Writing correct formulas, avoiding calculation mistakes, controlling complex expressions, and building scoring or filtering rules in analysis scripts.

Python Lists

Lists

A list is used to store multiple values in one variable. Lists are ordered, and you can change their items later, which makes them very useful for real programs.

In biology, lists are used to store things like sequences, gene names, sample IDs, scores, or counts.

In this topic, you will learn:

  • Creating a list
  • Accessing list items
  • Changing list values
  • Adding and removing items
  • List comprehension for fast filtering and building lists
  • Sorting, copying, and joining lists
  • Common list methods

By the end of this topic, you will be able to manage groups of data using lists in normal Python scripts and biology scripts.

Creating List

A list is created when you want to store multiple values together in a single variable instead of using many separate variables.

In Python, a list is written using square brackets [ ], and the values inside are separated by commas.

Lists can store numbers, text, or a mix of different data types.

Tuples

A tuple is used to store multiple values together in a single variable, similar to a list, but tuples are not meant to be changed after creation.

Tuples are written using parentheses ( ), and the values inside are separated by commas.

Tuples are useful when you want fixed data like coordinates, constant labels, or structured records.

Tuples keep values grouped and protect them from accidental changes.

Sets

A set is a data structure used to store multiple values in a single variable, where each value is unique.

Unlike lists and tuples, a set does not allow duplicate values and does not keep items in a fixed order.

Sets are mainly used when you care about whether a value exists or not, and when you want to automatically remove duplicates.

How sets are different from lists and tuples

Sets focus on uniqueness, not on position or order of elements.

  • Lists keep order and allow duplicates
  • Tuples keep order and allow duplicates
  • Sets do not keep order and do not allow duplicates

What sets are good at

Sets are very fast for checking membership and removing duplicates from data.

Biology examples

In biological data analysis, uniqueness is very important.

Example

Example

Used in: removing duplicates, checking unique gene or sample names, and working with unique result collections.

Creating sets

Creating a set means defining a collection of unique values stored together in a single variable.

In Python, sets are created using curly braces { } or the set() function.

You can create a set by placing values inside curly braces.

Example

Creating a set with duplicate values

Duplicate values are automatically removed in a set.

Example

Creating an empty set

Example

Biology examples

Creating sets is useful when you want only unique biological values.

Example

Example

Used in: initializing unique gene lists, creating unique sample collections, and preparing data for set operations.

Accessing set items

Sets do not support indexing because they do not keep items in a fixed order.

You cannot access a set item by position, but you can check whether a value exists or loop through all items.

Checking if a value exists using in

You can use in to test whether a value is present in a set.

Example

You can read all items in a set using a for loop.

You can also check that a value is not present in a set.

Sets do not support indexing, so this will cause an error.

Dictionaries

A dictionary is a data structure used to store information in key–value pairs.

Instead of storing single values like lists or tuples, dictionaries store data as named fields.

Each key is used to identify and access its corresponding value.

Dictionaries are written using curly braces {} with key: value pairs.

Keys are unique, but values can be repeated.

What you will learn in this topic

  • Create dictionaries
  • Access values using keys
  • Change existing values
  • Add and remove key–value pairs
  • Copy dictionaries

Why dictionaries are important

  • Result summaries and annotations

Decision Making

Decision making in Python means controlling the flow of a program based on conditions.

Instead of always running code from top to bottom, decision making allows the program to choose what to do next.

In Python, decisions are made using conditions that evaluate to either True or False.

A condition is usually created using comparison operators like >, <, ==, !=, >=, <=.

Why decision making is important

In real programs, data is not always the same, so the program must behave differently for different inputs.

For example, a program may need to check whether a sequence is valid, whether a value is above a threshold, or whether a result passes some rule.

Basic idea of conditional execution

When a condition is True, a block of code runs.

When the condition is False, that block of code is skipped.

Example

Understanding the flow

Only the code inside the condition block depends on the condition.

The rest of the program continues normally.

Example

Conditions are based on comparisons

Conditions are built using comparison operators.

Example

Biology-style thinking example

In bioinformatics and data analysis, decisions are everywhere, for example checking whether a sequence is long enough or whether a value crosses a cutoff.

Example

What you will learn in this topic

  • Run code only when a condition is true
  • Choose between multiple paths
  • Combine conditions
  • Write nested decisions
  • Handle cases where no action is needed
  • Apply decision logic to biological data problems

If

The if statement is used to run a block of code only when a condition is true.

It is the simplest form of decision making and is the base for all other conditional logic.

Basic structure of if

An if statement checks a condition, and if the condition is true, the indented block runs.

Example

Nothing happens when the condition is false

If the condition is false, the code inside the if block is skipped.

Example

Using variables in conditions

The condition usually depends on variables and their values.

Example

Using calculations inside conditions

You can use expressions and calculations inside the condition.

Example

Multiple statements inside one if block

An if block can contain more than one statement.

Elif

The elif statement is used to check another condition when the previous if condition is false.

It allows a program to choose between more than two possible paths.

Why elif is needed

Using only if is not enough when you want to test multiple conditions in order.

elif lets you check the next condition only if the previous one failed.

Basic structure with if and elif

The conditions are checked from top to bottom, and the first true block is executed.

Example

Only one block runs

Even if multiple conditions are true, only the first matching block is executed.

The three logical operators

Python Match

The match statement is used to compare a value against multiple patterns and execute different code blocks based on which pattern matches.

It works like a cleaner and more readable alternative to long if-elif-else chains when you are checking the same variable against many values.

Why match is useful

When you have many conditions that depend on the same variable, match makes the code easier to read and maintain.

Instead of writing many elif statements, you can group all cases in one structure.

Basic idea

You give a value to match and define multiple case blocks, and the block whose case matches the value will run.

Only one matching case is executed.

Comparison with if-elif

With if-elif, each condition is checked one by one, but with match, Python directly selects the matching case.

This makes decision logic clearer when handling categories, types, or fixed options.

Important notes

  • match is available in Python 3.10 and above
  • case _ means default case (like else)
  • match is best when checking one variable against many fixed patterns

Match statement basics

The match statement compares one value against several case patterns and runs the matching block.

It is mainly used when you want to select actions based on exact values or categories.

Basic match structure

A simple match has one match line and multiple case blocks.

Example

Using default case

The default case runs when no other case matches. Here case _ means anything else.

Example

Match with strings

Example

Match with categories

Example

Biology examples

Example

Example

Loops

A loop is a programming structure that allows the same block of code to run again and again automatically.

Instead of writing the same code many times, a loop lets you write it once and tell Python how many times or until when it should repeat.

Why loops are needed

In real programs, we often need to process many sequences, check many values, go through long lists of data, or analyze large datasets.

Doing this one by one manually is impossible. Loops solve this by automating repetition.

The core idea of a loop

A loop has three conceptual parts: a starting point, a condition or collection, and a repeating action.

The loop keeps running the same block of code until the condition is no longer true or the collection is finished.

How a loop works (step-by-step thinking)

Python takes one item or one step, runs the code block, moves to the next item or next step, and repeats this until there is nothing left to process.

So a loop is not magic, it is just controlled repetition.

Two main types of loops in Python

Python mainly uses two kinds of loops: for loop for iterating over collections, and while loop for repeating while a condition is true.

We will study both in detail in the next subtopics.

What loops help you do in real programs

Loops are used to read sequences character by character, process lists of genes or samples, count values, search for patterns, and apply the same rule to many items.

Almost all real data processing programs depend on loops.

Important mental model

A loop means: Do this same job again and again, changing only the data each time.

For loop

A for loop is used to repeat a block of code once for each item in a collection.

It is mainly used when you already have a group of items (like a list, string, or range) and you want to process each item one by one.

What the for loop does (conceptually)

A for loop:

  • Takes one item from a collection
  • Stores it in a variable
  • Runs the code block
  • Moves to the next item
  • Repeats this until all items are processed

So the loop automatically walks through the data for you.

Basic structure of a for loop

Example

Here:

  • item is a variable that changes each time
  • collection is the data you are looping over

Looping over a list

Example

This prints each number one by one.

Looping over a string

A string is a collection of characters, so the loop runs once for each character.

For this code:

Example

Python does this internally:

  • First round → x = 5 → print(5)
  • Second round → x = 8 → print(8)
  • Third round → x = 2 → print(2)
  • Then the loop stops

Using calculations inside a for loop

Example

The same operation is applied to each item automatically.

Biology examples

For loops are used to process sequences and biological lists item by item.

Example

Example

While loop

A while loop is used to repeat a block of code as long as a condition is true.

It is mainly used when you do not know in advance how many times the loop should run, but you know when it should stop.

What the while loop does (conceptually)

A while loop:

  • First checks a condition
  • If the condition is true, it runs the code block
  • After running, it checks the condition again
  • It keeps repeating this until the condition becomes false

So the loop is controlled by a condition, not by a fixed number of items.

Basic structure of a while loop

Example

Here:

  • condition must be a True or False expression
  • The loop runs only while the condition stays True

Why updating the condition variable is important

If you forget to change the variable used in the condition, the loop will never stop.

Example

This creates an infinite loop because i never changes.

A while loop is useful when you want to keep checking something until a condition is satisfied.

When you use a loop on a string:

  • Python takes the first character
  • Runs the code block
  • Moves to the next character
  • Repeats this until the string ends

So the loop automatically walks through every character.

A list is a collection of multiple values stored together, and looping over a list means processing each item one by one automatically.

Instead of writing separate code for each item, a loop allows you to apply the same operation to every element in the list.

Why we loop over lists

In real programs, lists often contain many numbers, many names, many sequences, or many results.

It is not practical to access and process each item manually, so loops are used to handle all items using one block of code.

How looping over a list works (conceptually)

When you loop over a list, Python takes the first item from the list, stores it in a variable, runs the code block, then takes the next item, and repeats this until the list ends.

So the loop automatically walks through the entire list for you.

Functions

A function is a named block of code that runs when you call it.

Functions help you avoid repeating the same code again and again by putting reusable logic in one place.

Why functions are important

When programs grow, the same steps often appear many times, like cleaning sequences, counting bases, checking thresholds, or formatting outputs.

A function lets you write that logic once and reuse it anywhere, which makes code easier to test, fix, and expand.

How functions work

A function usually has three parts:

  • Inputs (optional)
  • Processing steps (the code inside)
  • Output (optional)

You define the function once, and then you call it whenever you need it.

Basic function example

Example

Difference between parameters and arguments

Parameters are written inside the function definition.

*args / **kwargs

Sometimes you do not know how many inputs a function will receive in advance.

*args and **kwargs allow a function to accept a variable number of values without fixing the count.

What is *args

*args means: collect all extra positional values into one variable.

Inside the function, Python stores these values as a tuple.

Using *args

Here, all numbers passed to the function are automatically packed into a tuple named args.

The loop then reads this tuple one by one and adds each value to total.

Example

What is **kwargs

**kwargs means: collect all named arguments into one variable.

Inside the function, Python stores them as a dictionary (key–value pairs).

Using **kwargs

Here, each named input becomes a key and value inside a dictionary called kwargs.

The loop reads the dictionary and prints each key with its value.

Example

Mixing normal arguments, *args, and **kwargs

Here, Python first puts extra positional values into a tuple, and then puts named values into a dictionary.

The order must always be: normal → *args → **kwargs.

Example

Why *args and **kwargs are useful

They are used when a function must work with unknown or changing number of inputs.

Scope and lifetime of variable

A variable does not exist everywhere in a program and does not live forever.

Scope means where a variable can be used, and lifetime means how long the variable exists in memory.

Local variables

A variable created inside a function is called a local variable.

It is created when the function starts and is destroyed when the function ends.

Example

Here, x is created when show_number() runs, and Python deletes it after the function finishes.

Global variables

A variable created outside all functions is called a global variable.

It is created when the program starts and can be used inside any function.

Example

Here, value exists for the entire program execution.

Local and global with same name

If a variable name exists both inside and outside a function, Python treats them as different variables.

Example

Here, the function uses its own local x, and the global x is not changed.

Using global keyword

If you want to modify a global variable from inside a function, you must use the global keyword.

This tells Python to use the same variable from outside, not create a new local one.

Example

Here, Python updates the same global count each time the function runs.

Lifetime of variables

Local variables exist only while the function is running.

Global variables exist until the program ends.

Example

Here, a is removed from memory as soon as demo() finishes.

Why scope and lifetime matter

They prevent name conflicts, control memory usage, and avoid accidental data changes.

Decorators

A decorator is a function that modifies another function without changing its original code.

It is used when you want to add extra behavior before or after a function runs.

Why decorators are needed

Sometimes many functions need the same extra work like logging, timing, or checking permissions.

Instead of rewriting the same code again and again, a decorator adds that behavior automatically.

Functions are objects in Python

In Python, a function can be stored in a variable and passed to another function.

When Python sees @my_decorator, it runs this assignment:

say_hello = my_decorator(say_hello)

So the original function is not lost, it is just wrapped.

Lambda

A lambda is a small anonymous function written in one line.

It is used when you need a quick function for a short task without defining a full function with `def`.

Why lambda is used

A normal function is best when logic is long or reused many times.

Lambda is useful when the logic is short and needed only once, especially inside functions like `sorted()`.

Recursion

Recursion is a technique where a function calls itself to solve a problem step by step.

It is useful when a problem can be broken into smaller versions of the same problem.

Why recursion is used

Some problems are naturally repetitive in structure, like counting down, breaking data into parts, or processing nested data.

Recursion lets the function solve a small part and trust itself to solve the rest.

Base case and recursive case

Every recursive function must have:

A base case that stops the recursion.

A recursive case that calls the function again with a smaller or simpler input.

A simple recursion example

Here, the function prints numbers from n down to 1.

Example

Here, each call reduces n by 1, and when n becomes 0, the function stops calling itself.

How recursion works internally

Each function call is stored in memory, and Python waits for the inner call to finish before continuing.

When the base case is reached, Python returns step by step to the first call.

Recursion for calculation

Here, the function calculates the factorial of a number.

Example

Here, the function keeps calling itself with smaller values until it reaches 1.

Why base case is important

Without a base case, the function will call itself forever and cause an error.

Recursion vs loop

Most recursive problems can also be solved using loops.

Recursion is chosen when the problem structure is naturally recursive and easier to express that way.

Biology examples

Here, recursion is used to count the length of a sequence by reducing it one base at a time.

Example

Here, the function removes one base each time and stops when the sequence becomes empty.

Here, recursion is used to count how many fragments are in a nested list of results.

Example

Here, the list becomes smaller in each call until it becomes empty.

Generators

Generators are a special kind of function that produce values one by one instead of returning all values at once.

They are used when working with large data or long sequences where creating everything at once is not efficient.

Why generators are needed

When a normal function returns a list, all values are created and stored in memory at once.

A generator creates values only when they are needed, which saves memory and time.

The yield keyword

A generator function uses the keyword yield instead of return.

When Python sees yield, it pauses the function and remembers its state, and continues from there next time.

A simple generator example

Here, the generator produces numbers from 1 to 5 one by one.

Example

Here, each next() call resumes the function from where it was paused and gives the next value.

Generator with a loop

Here, the generator produces a sequence of numbers using a loop.

Example

Here, the function does not finish completely, it pauses at each yield and continues later.

Difference between return and yield

A function with return finishes completely and sends back one value.

A function with yield pauses and continues, producing many values over time.

How Python handles generators internally

Python does not run the whole function at once.

It runs the function only until the next yield, then stops and waits for the next request.

Biology examples

Here, a generator produces one DNA base at a time from a sequence.

Example

Here, each base is produced one by one instead of creating a list of bases.

Here, a generator produces sequence lengths one by one from a list.

Example

Here, values are generated only when requested, not stored all at once.

Modules and import

A module is a file that contains Python code such as functions, variables, or classes.

Using modules allows programs to be organized into separate files instead of keeping everything in one place.

Why modules are used

Large programs become easier to manage when code is split into meaningful parts.

Modules also allow reusing code across many programs without rewriting it.

What import does

The import statement tells Python to load code from another file or library so it can be used in the current program.

After importing, the functions and variables inside that module become available.

Modular programming

Modular programming means writing a program as a set of small parts instead of one long file.

Each part focuses on one job, and those parts are combined to make the full program.

Why modular programming is used

Large scripts become hard to read and fix when everything is in one place.

Splitting code into modules makes it easier to test, reuse, and update without breaking other parts.

File Handling

In real programs, data is not always typed by the user or kept only in variables. Most programs need to read data from files and write results back to files.

File handling means working with files to store data permanently, read existing data, update it, or process large data stored outside the program.

A file is simply a place on disk where data is stored in text or binary form.

In Python, file handling is done using built-in functions and file objects.

Basic idea of file handling

The basic workflow of file handling always follows three steps: 1. Open the file 2. Do some operation (read, write, or both) 3. Close the file

Opening a file creates a connection between your program and the file on disk.

Python uses the open() function to open files.

When a file is opened, Python returns a file object that is used to perform operations on that file.

Files can be opened in different modes depending on what you want to do:
- Read mode: open a file only for reading
- Write mode: open a file for writing (this can overwrite existing data)
- Append mode: open a file to add new data at the end
- Create mode: create a new file

Text files and data files

Most biological data files like FASTA, GenBank, and CSV are text files, which means they store data as readable text.

Python treats these files as normal text files, so the same file handling techniques work for all of them.

Why file handling is important in biology and data analysis

In real analysis work, data is usually stored in files, not typed manually.

Sequences, annotations, sample lists, results, and reports are almost always stored in files.

So learning file handling is necessary to work with real biological datasets and real analysis pipelines.

What you will learn in this topic

In this topic, you will learn how to:
- Read data from files
- Write and create files
- Delete files safely
- Handle errors using try/except
- Work with FASTA and GenBank files
- Read CSV files for tabular data

Read file

Reading a file means loading data that is already stored on disk into your Python program so you can process or analyze it.

Instead of typing large data manually, programs usually read data from files.

In Python, files are read using the open() function and file objects.

Opening a file in read mode

To read a file, you must open it in read mode using "r".

When a file is opened in read mode, Python connects your program to that file and allows you to fetch its contents.

Reading the entire file at once

You can read the full content of a file at once using the read() method.

This loads the whole file into memory as one string.

Reading a file line by line

Sometimes files are large, so it is better to read them line by line.

You can use a loop to read each line one by one.

Example

Each iteration gives one line from the file.

Reading only one line

You can also read just one line using the readline() method.

Example

Closing the file

After finishing reading, the file should be closed to free system resources.

Using with statement (recommended)

Python provides the with statement to automatically open and close files safely.

Example

When the block ends, the file is closed automatically.

Write/Create file

Writing to a file means saving data from your Python program into a file on disk.

If the file does not exist, Python can create a new file automatically.

If the file already exists, writing to it can overwrite the old content.

Opening a file in write mode

To write to a file, you must open it in write mode using "w".

When a file is opened in write mode, Python prepares the file to receive new data.

If the file already exists, its previous content will be erased.

Writing data to a file

You can write text to a file using the write() method.

Writing multiple lines

You can write multiple lines by calling write() many times or by writing newline characters.

Closing the file after writing

After writing, you must close the file so that all data is properly saved.

Using with statement for writing

Using with is safer because it closes the file automatically.

Delete file

Deleting a file means removing it permanently from the disk.

Once a file is deleted, its data is usually not recoverable, so deletion must be done carefully.

In Python, files are deleted using functions from the os module.

Using os.remove() to delete a file

The os.remove() function is used to delete a file by giving its file name or path.

Example

If the file exists, it will be deleted immediately.

If the file does not exist, Python will raise an error.

Checking if a file exists before deleting

To avoid errors, it is safer to check whether the file exists before trying to delete it.

You can use os.path.exists() for this check.

Example

Deleting a file after finishing work

Sometimes files are created temporarily during a program and should be deleted after use.

This helps to keep the folder clean and avoids using outdated files.

Deleting files and safety

You should never delete important files without checking their names and paths carefully.

Always be sure that you are deleting the correct file.

Try/Except (Error handling)

When a program runs, sometimes errors happen and the program stops suddenly.

Error handling means writing code in a way that prevents the program from crashing and allows it to handle problems safely.

In Python, errors are handled using try and except blocks.

Basic try and except

The code that might cause an error is written inside the try block.

If an error happens, Python jumps to the except block instead of stopping the program.

Example

If no error happens, the except block is skipped.

Catching specific errors

Instead of catching all errors, you can catch specific types of errors.

This makes error handling more accurate and safer.

Example

Using else with try/except

The else block runs only if no error happens in the try block.

Example

Using finally

The finally block always runs, whether an error happens or not.

It is commonly used to close files or clean up resources.

Example

Why error handling is important

Without error handling, a small problem can stop the whole program.

With error handling, the program can continue running or show a meaningful message.

FASTA format

FASTA is one of the most common text formats used to store biological sequences.

A FASTA file stores sequence records using a header line and one or more sequence lines.

The header line starts with the ">" symbol and usually contains an ID and description.

The sequence lines contain the DNA, RNA, or protein letters.

Biopython

Biopython is a Python library that helps you work with biological data like DNA, RNA, protein sequences, and common bioinformatics file formats.

It gives ready-to-use tools so you can focus on biology tasks instead of writing everything from scratch.

What Biopython helps you do

You can create sequences, read and write FASTA and GenBank files, extract annotations, and fetch data from NCBI.

Biopython is useful for building small scripts as well as full bioinformatics pipelines.

The core idea

Biopython provides special objects like Seq and SeqRecord that behave like normal Python objects but understand biology operations.

This makes tasks like transcription and translation simple and readable.

Example

This creates a DNA sequence, transcribes it to RNA, and slices the first codon.

Important modules you will use

Seq is used for sequence operations, SeqIO is used for reading and writing sequence files, and Entrez is used for connecting to NCBI.

You will learn how these modules work and how to combine them in practical tasks.

What you will learn in this topic

  • Install Biopython and verify it works
  • Understand Seq and SeqRecord basics
  • Read and write FASTA files using SeqIO
  • Read GenBank files and understand what they contain
  • Extract features and qualifiers from GenBank annotations
  • Use Entrez to search and fetch data from NCBI
  • Practice small workflows that look like real bioinformatics scripts

Biopython is commonly used for tasks like translating genes, reading genome fragments from FASTA, extracting CDS regions from GenBank, and downloading sequences by accession number.

What is Biopython

Biopython is a Python library specially made for biological and bioinformatics work.

It provides ready-made tools to work with DNA, RNA, protein sequences, and biological files.

Instead of writing everything from scratch, Biopython gives you powerful building blocks for bioinformatics programs.

Why Biopython is needed

Biological data is large and complex, and normal Python strings and files are not enough for serious analysis.

Biopython provides special objects and functions to handle sequences, annotations, and databases easily.

It saves time and reduces mistakes when working with biological data.

What kinds of problems Biopython helps solve

Biopython is used to read and write FASTA and GenBank files, analyze sequences, and communicate with online databases.

It is also used to translate DNA to protein, find motifs, and manage sequence annotations.

You can build real bioinformatics pipelines using Biopython.

Medline Parses PubMed / Medline records

These modules together allow you to read data, analyze sequences, run alignments, access databases, and process biological results.

Sequence Parsing

Sequence parsing means reading biological sequence files and converting them into Python objects that your program can work with.

In real bioinformatics, most data comes from files like FASTA and GenBank, not from manual input.

Why parsing is important

Without parsing, sequence data is just text and cannot be analyzed or filtered easily.

With parsing, you can loop through sequences, extract information, and build analysis pipelines.

What you will do in this topic

You will learn how to read FASTA and GenBank files, filter sequences, create custom lists, and write new files.

You will also practice combining different parsing steps to solve real biological data problems.

A simple idea of parsing

"example.fasta" file contains

    >BRCA1_Homo_sapiens_partial_cds
    ATGGATTTATCTGCTCTTCGCGTTGAAGAAGTACAAAATGTCAGGACT
    TCTGCTGCTGCTGATGATGACGATGATGATGCTGCTGCTGCTGATGAT
    GATGCTGATGATGACGATGATGATGCTGCTGCTGCTGATGATGATGCT
    GATGATGACGATGATGATGCTGCTGCTGCTGATGATGATGCTGATGAT
    GACGATGATGAT

Instead of reading a file as plain text, Biopython gives you records that already understand sequence, ID, and annotations.

Example

This reads a FASTA file and prints the ID and length of each sequence.

Why parsing matters

In bioinformatics, almost all data comes from files like FASTA and GenBank, not from manual input.

These files can be very large and contain many sequences and annotations.

Problem with reading as plain text

If you read these files as normal text, you must manually find IDs, sequences, and features using string operations.

This is slow, error-prone, and hard to maintain.

What parsing gives you

Parsing converts raw text files into structured Python objects like SeqRecord.

These objects already know their ID, sequence, and annotations.

Example

Here you just get text, not structured biological information.

Example

Here you directly get sequence IDs and sequence objects.

Why this matters in real work

Parsing allows you to loop over thousands of sequences, filter them, extract features, and write results automatically.

Almost all real bioinformatics pipelines start with parsing.

DNA, RNA, and Protein

This topic introduces biological sequences and how DNA, RNA, and proteins are represented and processed in Python.

You will learn how to work with sequences, transcribe DNA to RNA, and translate DNA or RNA into protein.

Sequence basics

In bioinformatics, a sequence means an ordered string of biological letters such as DNA, RNA, or protein.

DNA uses A, T, G, C, RNA uses A, U, G, C, and proteins use 20 different amino acid letters.

DNA, RNA, and protein as simple strings

At the most basic level, a sequence can be stored and handled as a normal Python string.

Example

Here sequences are just text, and Python does not know they are biological.

Common operations on sequences

You often need to check length, access specific positions, or take parts of a sequence.

Example

This prints the length, the first base, and the first codon.

Why plain strings are not enough

Using plain strings does not give built-in biological operations like transcription or translation.

For that, Biopython provides special sequence objects.

Using Biopython Seq object

The Seq object knows that the string is a biological sequence and supports biological operations.

Example

This looks like a string, but it is now a biological sequence object.

Example

This shows how sequence length is used to make biological decisions.

Using Seq objects

The Seq object is Biopython’s main way to represent biological sequences with built-in biological operations.

It behaves like a string but also understands operations like transcription, translation, and complement.

Creating a Seq object

You create a Seq object from a normal Python string.

Example

This shows that seq is a Seq object, not a normal string.

Seq objects act like strings

You can index, slice, and get length just like a string.

Converting Seq to string

Sometimes you need to convert a Seq object back to a normal string.

This converts the biological sequence back into plain text.

Why Seq is better than string

Seq objects provide built-in methods for biological tasks.

For example, you can get complement, reverse complement, or translate without writing your own code.

Example

This gives the complement and reverse complement automatically.

DNA to RNA

Converting DNA to RNA is called transcription, where T is replaced by U in the sequence.

In biology, this step prepares the DNA information to be used for making proteins.

Manual conversion using string

At the basic level, you can convert DNA to RNA by replacing all T with U.

Example

This works, but it does not check if the sequence is really DNA.

Using Biopython Seq object

The Seq object provides a built-in method to transcribe DNA into RNA correctly.

Example

This automatically converts T to U and returns an RNA sequence.

Checking the result type

The result is still a Seq object, but now it represents RNA.

Example

This confirms that RNA is also handled as a Seq object.

Why use transcribe instead of replace

Using transcribe makes the code clearer and avoids mistakes when working with real biological data.

It also fits naturally into further steps like translation.

RNA to DNA

Converting RNA back to DNA is called reverse transcription, where U is replaced by T.

This step is common in labs when working with cDNA made from mRNA.

Manual conversion using string

At the basic level, you can convert RNA to DNA by replacing all U with T.

Example

This works, but it does not check if the sequence is really RNA.

Using Biopython Seq object

The Seq object provides a built-in method to back-transcribe RNA into DNA.

This automatically converts U to T and returns a DNA sequence.

Checking the result type

The result is still a Seq object, but now it represents DNA.

Example

This confirms that the result is handled as a Seq object.

Why use back_transcribe instead of replace

Using back_transcribe makes the biological meaning clear and avoids mistakes in real workflows.

It also keeps the code consistent with other Biopython operations.

DNA/RNA to protein

Converting a nucleotide sequence into a protein sequence is called translation.

In biology, this reads the sequence three bases at a time (codons) and converts them into amino acids.

Translation using Biopython Seq

The Seq object provides a built-in method to translate DNA or RNA into protein.

Example

This reads the DNA in codons and produces a protein sequence.

Translating RNA directly

You can also translate RNA sequences directly using the same method.

Example

This works the same way because Biopython understands both DNA and RNA alphabets.

What happens to stop codons

Stop codons are translated as * in the protein sequence.

Example

The * symbol marks the position of a stop codon.

Why correct reading frame matters

If the sequence is not in the correct frame, translation gives the wrong protein.

This is why start position and frame selection are important in gene analysis.

Start and stop codons

In protein-coding DNA, translation does not start at any random position. It starts at a start codon and ends at a stop codon.

The most common start codon is ATG (which codes for Methionine), and common stop codons are TAA, TAG, and TGA.

Finding start codon in a sequence

You can scan a DNA sequence to find where the first start codon appears.

Example

This tells you where translation could begin.

Finding all stop codons

You can scan the sequence codon by codon and look for stop codons.

Example

This checks the sequence in steps of three bases (codons).

Translating only from start codon

In real genes, translation starts at the first ATG and stops at the first stop codon after it.

Example

This simulates how a coding region is translated in real biology.

Why start and stop codons matter

Without a correct start codon, translation will begin in the wrong place. Without a stop codon, translation will continue and produce a wrong or incomplete protein.

Checking for valid start and stop codons is a basic step in gene prediction and ORF finding.

Reading frames

A reading frame means how a DNA or RNA sequence is split into groups of three bases (codons) for translation.

The same sequence has three possible reading frames depending on where you start reading.

The three possible frames

Frame 1 starts from position 0, frame 2 from position 1, and frame 3 from position 2.

Example

You can see that each frame produces a different protein sequence.

Why only one frame is correct for a gene

Real genes are encoded in only one correct reading frame. The other frames usually contain many stop codons.

Finding the best looking frame

A simple way is to check which frame gives the longest protein without many stop codons.

Example

The correct frame often looks more like a real protein and less broken by stop codons.

Reading frames in reverse strand

In real genomes, genes can also be on the reverse strand, so those frames must also be checked.

Example

Together, this makes six possible reading frames for any DNA sequence.

Complement sequences

In DNA, each base pairs with its complement: A pairs with T, and C pairs with G.

The complement of a sequence is formed by replacing each base with its pairing base.

Getting the complement using Biopython

The Seq object has a built-in method to get the complement.

Example

This creates the complementary strand but keeps the same direction.

Reverse complement

In biology, we usually work with the reverse complement because DNA strands run in opposite directions.

Example

This both complements the bases and reverses the sequence direction.

Why reverse complement is important

Genes can be located on either strand of DNA, so you must often check the reverse complement for coding regions.

Checking if a sequence is palindromic

A DNA sequence is palindromic if it is the same as its reverse complement.

Example

Many restriction enzyme sites are palindromic sequences.

Example

This shows why both strands must be checked during gene finding.

This is useful when you want to simulate mutations, fix errors, or modify a region of a sequence.

ORF and CDS checks

An ORF (Open Reading Frame) is a region of DNA that starts with a start codon and ends with a stop codon without breaks.

A CDS (Coding Sequence) is an ORF that is believed to really code for a protein.

Checking if a sequence has a valid start and stop

A simple CDS should start with ATG and end with one of the stop codons.

This checks the most basic properties of a coding sequence.

Seq vs SeqRecord

In Biopython, Seq represents only a biological sequence, while SeqRecord represents a sequence together with its information like ID, name, and description.

You can think of Seq as just the letters, and SeqRecord as the full record about that sequence.

Creating a Seq object

A Seq object stores only the sequence and supports biological operations like translate and complement.

This object knows nothing about where the sequence came from, it only stores the letters.

This is because real biological data always comes with IDs, names, and annotations.

Accessing NCBI and BLAST through Biopython

Biopython allows Python programs to directly communicate with NCBI databases and online tools like BLAST.

This makes it possible to search, download, and analyze biological data automatically instead of using the browser.

In this topic, you will learn how to fetch sequences from NCBI, download FASTA files, run BLAST, and read the results using Biopython.

These tools are widely used in real bioinformatics pipelines and research workflows.

Entrez basics

Entrez is the system used by NCBI to access databases like Nucleotide, Protein, and PubMed.

Biopython provides the Bio.Entrez module to talk to NCBI servers from Python.

Before using Entrez, you must tell NCBI who you are by setting your email address.

Setting up Entrez email

NCBI requires an email address so they can contact you if there is a problem with your requests.

Example

This must be done once in your script before making any NCBI request.

This returns how many records match the search term.

Getting ID list from a search

Example

These IDs are used in the next steps to fetch full records or sequences.

Why Entrez is important

Entrez is the main gateway for accessing NCBI data programmatically in Biopython.

All downloading and BLAST-related operations depend on this interface.

Fetching sequences

After searching NCBI and getting record IDs, the next step is to download the full sequence records.

This is done using Entrez.efetch(), which fetches data from NCBI by ID.

Fetching a record by ID

You must provide the database name, the ID, and the format you want.

Why fetching is important

Fetching sequences is the main way to build local datasets from NCBI for analysis and pipelines.

Almost all automated bioinformatics workflows start by fetching data like this.

This creates a local FASTA file that can be used by other tools.

Downloading multiple FASTA sequences

You can also download multiple sequences at once by giving multiple IDs.

Example

This returns multiple FASTA records in one output.

When FASTA is preferred

FASTA is used when you only care about the sequence itself and not the detailed annotations.

It is the most common format for running tools like BLAST.

Run BLAST

BLAST is used to find similar sequences in large databases.

Biopython allows you to run online BLAST searches from Python using the Bio.Blast module.

Running an online BLAST search

You can send a sequence to NCBI BLAST servers using NCBIWWW.qblast().

Example

Note: Running blast example may take a bit more time then usual

This sends the sequence to NCBI and starts a BLAST search.

Saving BLAST results to a file

BLAST results are returned as XML text, so you usually save them to a file.

Example

This stores the BLAST output so it can be analyzed later.

Important note about BLAST usage

Online BLAST is slow and should not be used in large loops or heavy pipelines.

For large jobs, you should use local BLAST installations instead.

Why BLAST from Python is useful

It allows you to automate similarity searches inside scripts and workflows.

This is useful for testing, small jobs, and teaching purposes.

BLAST results

BLAST results are usually returned in XML format when using Biopython.

You must parse this XML file to extract useful information like hits, scores, and alignments.

Parsing BLAST XML results

Biopython provides Bio.Blast.NCBIXML to read BLAST XML output.

Example

This loads the BLAST result file and prints the query name.

Listing all hits

Each BLAST result contains many alignments (hits).

Example

This prints the title of each hit found by BLAST.

Reading scores and e-values

Each alignment contains one or more high-scoring pairs (HSPs) with scores and e-values.

Example

This prints the score and e-value for each HSP.

Why parsing BLAST results is important

BLAST output is large and complex, so parsing is required to automatically extract useful information.

This allows you to filter, rank, and analyze hits inside your scripts.

Usage rules

NCBI provides free services, but they have strict usage rules to prevent abuse.

When using Biopython to access NCBI, you must follow these rules or your access may be blocked.

Always set your email

You must always set Entrez.email before making any request.

Example

This allows NCBI to contact you if there is a problem with your requests.

Do not send too many requests

You should not send many requests in a short time.

Always add delays between requests in scripts.

Example

This pauses the program for one second before sending the next request.

Use API key if you have one

If you have an NCBI API key, you can set it to increase your request limit.

Example

This allows more requests per second, but rules still apply.

Why these rules matter

Following these rules keeps the NCBI servers available for everyone.

Ignoring them can cause your IP address to be blocked.

Data Visualization with Matplotlib and Seaborn

Data visualization is the process of turning numerical data into graphs and plots so patterns can be seen easily.

In bioinformatics, plots are used to understand sequence properties, gene expression values, and many other results.

Python provides two very popular libraries for plotting: matplotlib and seaborn.

Matplotlib is the base plotting library, and seaborn is built on top of it to make nicer and easier plots.

In this topic, you will learn how to create simple plots, visualize GC content, base composition, gene expression, and save figures.

These skills are essential for analyzing and presenting biological data.

Plotting setup

Before creating any plot, you must import the plotting libraries and prepare the environment.

Most plots in Python are created using matplotlib.pyplot, and seaborn works on top of it.

Importing matplotlib

The standard way is to import pyplot as plt.

Example

This gives you access to all basic plotting functions.

Importing seaborn

Seaborn is usually imported as sns.

Example

Seaborn uses matplotlib internally but provides simpler functions and better default styles.

Showing a plot window

After creating a plot, you must call plt.show() to display it.

Example

Without this, the plot may not appear in normal Python scripts.

Setting a default seaborn style

Seaborn can change the look of all matplotlib plots using a theme.

Example

This makes plots look cleaner without changing your plotting code.

Minimal working plotting template

Most plotting scripts follow this basic structure.

Example

All future plots in this topic will follow this setup pattern.

Basic plots

The most common plots are line plots, bar plots, and scatter plots.

These are enough to visualize most simple biological and numerical data.

Line plot

A line plot is used to show how a value changes across positions or time.

Example

This draws a line connecting all the points.

Bar plot

A bar plot is used to compare values between categories.

Example

Each bar represents one category.

Scatter plot

A scatter plot is used to see the relationship between two values.

Example

Each point is drawn separately instead of connecting them.

Why these three plots matter

Almost all scientific plots are built using combinations of these basic plot types.

Understanding these three makes it easy to learn more advanced plotting.

GC content plots

GC content is the percentage of G and C bases in a DNA sequence.

Plotting GC content helps you visualize how it changes across a sequence or between samples.

GC content along a sequence

One common approach is to calculate GC content in windows and plot the values.

Example

This shows how GC percentage changes along the sequence.

Comparing GC content of multiple sequences

You can also compare GC percentages of different sequences using a bar plot.

Example

This makes it easy to see which sequence has higher or lower GC content.

Why GC plots are useful

GC content is related to genome structure, stability, and some biological properties.

Visualizing it helps detect unusual regions or compare samples quickly.

Base composition plots

Base composition means counting how many A, T, G, and C bases are in a sequence.

Plotting these counts helps you see the overall nucleotide balance of a sequence.

Counting bases in a sequence

First, you count how many times each base appears.

Example

This creates a dictionary with counts of each base.

Plotting base composition as a bar chart

A bar chart is a simple way to compare the four base counts.

Example

This shows how many times each base appears in the sequence.

Using a pie chart for base composition

A pie chart shows the relative proportions of each base.

Example

This makes it easy to see which base is most common.

Why base composition plots matter

They help detect unusual nucleotide distributions and compare sequences.

Many quality control checks start by looking at base composition.

Gene expression plots

Gene expression values are usually numbers that show how active a gene is in a sample.

Plotting these values helps you compare genes or samples visually.

Bar plot for gene expression

A bar plot is commonly used to compare expression values of different genes.

Example

This shows which genes are more or less expressed.

Line plot for expression across samples

If you track one gene across samples or time points, a line plot is useful.

Example

This makes trends across samples easy to see.

Using seaborn for nicer expression plots

Seaborn provides simpler functions and better default styles.

Example

The result looks cleaner without extra code.

Why expression plots are important

They help compare genes, detect outliers, and understand biological differences between samples.

Almost all gene expression analysis uses plots like these.

Saving figures

After creating a plot, you often want to save it as an image file instead of only showing it on the screen.

Saved figures can be used in reports, presentations, papers, or websites.

Using savefig()

Matplotlib provides the savefig() function to save the current figure to a file.

Example

This saves the figure as a PNG image in the current folder.

Saving in different formats

You can save the same figure in formats like PNG, JPG, PDF, or SVG by changing the file extension.

Example

The same plot is saved in two different file formats.

Controlling image quality

You can control the resolution using the dpi option.

Example

Higher DPI means a sharper image, which is useful for printing or papers.

Saving before or after show()

It is a good habit to call savefig() before show().

This avoids problems where the figure might be cleared after showing.

Why saving figures is important

Analysis results are often communicated using figures, not raw numbers.

Being able to save clean, high-quality plots is an essential data analysis skill.

Handling Lab Data in Excel/CSV Using Pandas

In real labs, most data is stored in tables like Excel files or CSV files.

These tables may contain gene expression values, sample information, or experiment results.

Python provides a very powerful library called pandas to work with such tabular data.

Pandas allows you to load data, clean it, filter it, analyze it, and save the results back to files.

Instead of writing long loops, you can do complex data operations using simple commands.

In this topic, you will learn how to load CSV and Excel files, clean and filter data, compute summary statistics, work with gene expression tables, merge tables, and export results.

These skills are essential for almost all real-world bioinformatics and lab data analysis work.

Pandas basics

Pandas is a Python library used to work with table-like data such as Excel sheets and CSV files.

The main data structure in pandas is called a DataFrame, which looks like a table with rows and columns.

Each column has a name, and each row represents one record (for example, one sample or one gene).

First, you need to import pandas. By convention, it is imported as pd.

Load CSV and Excel

Most lab data is stored in CSV files or Excel files.

Pandas can load these files directly into a DataFrame so you can work with them like a table.

Advanced Python Tools

As your programs become larger and more powerful, you will need more advanced tools provided by Python.

These tools help you handle structured data, work with time, manage packages, optimize performance, and write more efficient code.

In this topic, you will learn about JSON for structured data, iterators for efficient looping, regular expressions for pattern matching, date and time handling, virtual environments, arrays for numeric data, and PIP for managing libraries.

These concepts are general programming tools, but they are extremely useful in biological data analysis and bioinformatics workflows.

You will see how these tools can be used for tasks like handling metadata, processing large datasets, searching patterns in sequences, managing project environments, and installing scientific libraries.

Learning these tools will make your Python skills much more practical and professional.

JSON

JSON is a text format used to store and exchange structured data using key and value pairs.

It looks similar to Python dictionaries and is commonly used to save settings, results, or metadata.

Python provides a built-in module called json to work with JSON data.

Converting a Python dictionary to JSON

You can convert a Python dictionary to a JSON string using json.dumps().

Example

This converts the Python data into a JSON formatted text string.

Reading JSON back into Python

You can convert a JSON string back into Python objects using json.loads().

Example

Now the JSON text is converted back into a Python dictionary.

You can save JSON data to a file using json.dump().

Example

Loading JSON from a file

You can load JSON data from a file using json.load().

Example

JSON is often used to store metadata such as sample information, analysis parameters, or results summaries.

Example

This saves biological sample information in a structured and easy-to-share format.

Iterators

An iterator is an object that allows you to go through values one by one instead of loading everything at once.

Iterators are useful when working with large data because they save memory.

In Python, many things like lists, files, and ranges already work as iterators.

Basic idea of an iterator

An iterator gives the next value only when you ask for it using next().

Example

Each call to next() gives the next value from the collection.

Iterators in for loops

A for loop automatically uses the iterator behind the scenes.

Example

The loop asks for the next value each time until there are no more values.

Creating your own iterator with yield

You can create a simple iterator using a function and the yield keyword.

Example

This produces numbers one by one instead of creating a full list.

Example

This reads one line at a time instead of loading the whole file into memory.

RegEx

Regular expressions (RegEx) are used to search, match, and extract patterns from text.

They are very powerful when you need to find specific formats like IDs, numbers, or patterns inside strings.

Python provides the re module to work with regular expressions.

Searching for a pattern in text

You can check whether a pattern exists in a string using re.search().

Example

This checks whether the pattern S1 exists in the text.

Extracting parts of text

You can extract matching parts using re.findall().

Example

This finds all numbers that appear in the text.

Replacing text using patterns

You can replace parts of text that match a pattern using re.sub().

Example

This replaces every number in the text with the letter X.

RegEx is useful for extracting IDs or annotations from sequence headers or result files.

Example

This extracts the accession ID from a FASTA header line.

Date/DateTime

Python provides tools to work with dates and times using the datetime module.

This is useful for recording when an experiment was run, when data was generated, or when files were created.

Virtual environment

A virtual environment is an isolated Python workspace where you can install libraries without affecting the system Python.

This helps avoid version conflicts between different projects.

Why virtual environments are useful

Different projects may need different versions of the same library, and virtual environments keep them separate.

Creating a virtual environment

You can create a virtual environment using the venv module.

Arrays

Arrays are used to store large collections of numbers in a compact and efficient way.

In scientific computing, arrays are commonly handled using the numpy library.

Arrays are faster and use less memory than normal Python lists for numeric data.

PIP

PIP is the package manager for Python that is used to install, update, and remove external libraries.

Many useful tools like Biopython, NumPy, Pandas, and Matplotlib are installed using PIP.
